title: Understanding Our Soil: The Nitrogen Cycle Fixers and Fertilizer

tasks.task: Farmer learns about the nitrogen cycle and how nitrogen-fixing plants benefit the garden.
subtasks: Understand the composition of Earth's atmosphere (78% nitrogen).
Recognize the non-reactive form of atmospheric nitrogen and its utility to plants.
Learn about bacteria's role in converting atmospheric nitrogen to plant-available forms (ammonium, nitrite, nitrate).
Understand the process of plants acquiring nutrients through root fungi.
Identify how nitrogen exits the soil and the role of anaerobic bacteria.
Realize the impact of water and harvesting on soil nitrogen levels.
Comprehend the benefits of nitrogen-fixing plants in maintaining soil fertility.
Compare the effects of synthetic fertilizer versus natural nitrogen fixation on soil and water quality.
Recognize the link between soil health and nutrient content in vegetables.

tasks.task: Plan to incorporate nitrogen-fixing plants into the garden.
subtasks: Select appropriate nitrogen-fixing plants (e.g., peas, beans, clover).
Determine the best method of integrating nitrogen-fixers (interplanting or cover crop).
Understand the role of nitrogen-fixing plant nodules and symbiotic bacteria.
Plan for the decomposition of nitrogen-fixing plants and its benefits to future crops.

tasks.task: Maintain soil health by preserving nutrient cycling.
subtasks: Investigate the role of earthworms and other microorganisms in soil health.
Learn about the balance between adding nutrients and supporting beneficial soil life.
Adjust farming practices to minimize disruption to the nitrogen cycle and soil food web.
